item.title: Huawei's Meng Wanzhou 'to be freed' in US deal
item.description: Chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou has been detained in Canada over US fraud charges since 2018.

item.title: Afghanistan: Executions will return, says senior Taliban official
item.description: Extreme punishments like executions and amputations will resume in Afghanistan, says the Taliban's head of prisons.

item.title: German election: Climate protesters rally in cities
item.description: They want the next government to do more to limit global heating and to end the use of coal.

item.title: Kim Yo-jong says North Korea open to ending war if conditions met
item.description: Kim Yo-jong was responding to a renewed call from the South to officially declare an end to the Korean War.

item.title: Migrants freezing to death on Belarus-Poland border
item.description: The BBC finds stranded migrants facing sub-zero temperatures amid a row between Poland and Belarus.

item.title: Canary Islands: Firefighters retreat as volcano intensifies
item.description: Hundreds of homes have been destroyed and thousands displaced since the volcano erupted on Sunday.

item.title: China declares all crypto-currency transactions illegal
item.description: Trading Bitcoin and other crypto-currenices is a criminal activity, China's central bank says.

item.title: Jitender Maan Gogi: India gangster shot dead in Delhi court
item.description: Two men dressed as lawyers opened fire in court on a man police detained on charges of murder and extortion.

item.title: Mozambique militant attacks: 'So much destruction'
item.description: The BBC's Anne Soy sees how Islamic militants have terrorised Cabo Delgado in northern Mozambique

item.title: Syria war: UN calculates new death toll
item.description: It says that the actual number is bound to be higher than its tally, 10 years after the war began.

item.title: Catalan exile Puigdemont freed by Italian court
item.description: Carles Puigdemont was detained in Italy over a failed Catalan bid to win independence.

item.title: Kenyan policeman wakes up from coma to find he was sacked
item.description: Neither his family nor the police force could locate Reuben Kimutai Lel, who was actually in hospital.

item.title: Haitian migrants at US border: 'We've been through 11 countries'
item.description: Fiterson's hellish seven-year journey through 11 countries explains migrants' desperation at US border.

item.title: Gabby Petito case: The missing Americans you don't hear about
item.description: Keen public interest in the Gabby Petito case has renewed the urgency of other missing person cases.

item.title: Angela Merkel: A career in pictures
item.description: As Angela Merkel steps down as German chancellor, we take a look back at the photos documenting her career.

item.title: Singapore migrant workers are still living in Covid lockdown
item.description: The workers in Singapore are enduring one of the longest Covid confinement periods in the world.

item.title: Africa's week in pictures: 17-23 September 2021
item.description: A selection of the best photos from the African continent and beyond.

item.title: New Zealand council's Zoom talks go viral as pretend meeting
item.description: A New Zealand committee meeting gets almost 300,000 views as people use it to avoid being disturbed.

item.title: German elections 2021: The conspiracy theories targeting voters
item.description: One wildly inaccurate claim suggests Germany does not actually exist.

item.title: Little Boots says Abba's new live band is 'badass cool'
item.description: The pop star is joining Abba's live band next year, after crowd-funding her sparkling new album.

item.title: Spying concerns fuel the market for more secure tech
item.description: Revelations about spyware have spurred interest in more secure phones and software.

item.title: Why are so many Haitians at the US-Mexico border?
item.description: Thousands of migrants are at the Texas-Mexico border. Here's what we know about why they are coming.

item.title: Thousands remain at Haitian migrant camp in Texas
item.description: Local officials have struggled to provide food and sanitation to the Haitian migrants.

item.title: Angela Merkel: What will Germans miss about the chancellor?
item.description: BBC Europe editor Katya Adler takes a road trip to find out how Germans will remember their chancellor.

item.title: Here’s a handful of facts about sign language
item.description: Sign language is an important way of communicating especially for the deaf community, but how much do you know about it?

item.title: Melbourne earthquake: Australians react to rare quake that rattled country
item.description: One resident thought the 5.9 magnitude quake was just his neighbours doing an intense workout.

item.title: Life at 50C: Heat hitting home in Australia
item.description: Cities like Sydney are already experiencing extremely hot days because of climate change.

item.title: German elections 2021: Simple guide to vote ending Merkel era
item.description: Germans are choosing a new government on Sunday. This is how the vote works.

item.title: German election: Who could succeed Angela Merkel as chancellor?
item.description: A lacklustre lead candidate and a surprisingly strong Social Democrat have blown the race wide open.

item.title: German elections 2021: 'Bazooka man' Olaf Scholz bidding for chancellor
item.description: The centre-left finance minister has led the polls in the run-up to the vote to succeed Angela Merkel.

item.title: German elections: How Angela Merkel changed her country
item.description: Young people have never known another leader, and many worry for the future as old certainties shift.

item.title: Angela Merkel: Four expert verdicts on a contested legacy
item.description: When the German chancellor steps down, how will history remember her? Four experts have their say.
